reasoning: Cruciality is high because the adjustment/reconfiguration timescale is a key pivot in the paper’s rebuttal to compute-bottleneck arguments: “days/weeks” vs “years/decades” materially changes expectations about early SIE acceleration and the feasibility of governance catching up. Paper-specificity is high because it directly targets the paper’s Jones-style claim that short-run complementarity could rapidly dissolve under abundant fast-thinking AGIs. Tractability is moderate-low: we can study organizational/process reconfiguration in R&D (e.g., lab throughput changes, automation adoption, parallelization limits, software-engineering scaling laws, historical cases of rapid workflow retooling under extreme incentives), but extrapolating to ‘millions of AGIs’ is highly uncertain and proxy-dependent. Clarity is fairly strong but still ambiguous about what counts as “reconfigure” and what metric defines “good use” (e.g., experiments/day, algorithmic progress rate, effective elasticity ρ shift). Decision hook is excellent because it explicitly links answer regimes to distinct governance strategies. Dead weight is low: most text sets scope, anchors to the paper, and states implications without excess.
title: Speed of AI R&D reconfiguration with abundant cognitive labor
